courses.name: Introduction to Music History and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: IIntroduction to form, style and the interrelationship of music and culture. A basic ability to read music is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Music History and Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Faculty of Music students cannot enroll in Arts & Science music courses.

cmCourseInfo.description:
Students rehearse and perform in concerts and reading sessions as assigned by the Faculty of Music. Provides experience in choral groups, orchestra, or in concert band and large wind groups of diverse instrumentation. Development of musicianship skills through performance of large ensemble works; emphasis on sight-reading, ear-training, and musical knowledge. Attendance at all sessions is required. Placement audition and permission of the Department required.
Download the excerpt that is relevant to the instrument you would like to audition on; excerpts will be available at www.music.utoronto.ca beginning early July. Complete and return the MUS120Y1 & MUS220Y1 Audition Request Form before August 17, 2018. Once your request form is received, you will be notified of your audition time. Placement audition will be held on September 4, 5 or 6, 2018 in the Edward Johnson Building. The audition will be 10 minutes in length.
cmCourseInfo.title: Vocal and Instrumental Ensembles I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Faculty of Music students cannot enroll in Arts & Science music courses. For 'E' indicator courses: contact the department for further information: (416) 978-3740; registrar.music@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of Beethoven’s musical style in historical context, including a non-technical consideration of Beethoven’s innovations based on listening to music and reading history. No prior background in music or ability to read music is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Beethoven

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Faculty of Music students cannot enroll in Arts & Science music courses.

cmCourseInfo.description: An investigation of the social life of classical, devotional, theatrical, folk, and popular music and dance across East Asia.
cmCourseInfo.title: Performing Arts of East Asia

Faculty of Music students cannot enroll in Arts & Science music courses. For 'E' indicator courses: contact the department for further information: (416) 978-3740; registrar.music@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of popular, folk, and religious music from Latin America and the Caribbean.  Each practice will be considered in its socio-cultural context with attention to the histories and discourses of racial and cultural mixing that deeply inform everyday life in nation-states including Peru, Brazil, Haiti, and Jamaica among others.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin American and Caribbean Music

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Faculty of Music students cannot enroll in Arts & Science music courses.

cmCourseInfo.description: In The Ultimate Encyclopedia Of Rock, it was written of the The Beatles that “From three-minute pop classics to the psychedelic extravaganza of ‘Sgt. Pepper’, their songs soundtracked the Sixties. They were the greatest group in history. They probably always will be”. In addition to a survey of the group’s history, their recordings, and their films, this course aims to answer two basic questions: (1) what made the songs of The Beatles so successful? (2) in what ways did the band’s artistic output “soundtrack” the 1960s? No prior background in music or ability to read music is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Beatles

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

cmCourseInfo.description: Selected works from the second half of the eighteenth century by Haydn, Mozart, and their contemporaries will be examined in cultural and historical context. No prior background in music or ability to read music is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Age of Haydn & Mozart
